message: P2 and P3, to avoid wasting the first turn with collisions, let's coordinate. I propose we each pick a unique number: I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. This way, we all advance and the game moves forward. If you agree, confirm. Otherwise, suggest an alternative.
I suggest we swap roles this turn: I (P3) pick 5, P2 picks 3, and P1 picks 1. That avoids collisions and helps me catch up. Are you both OK with that?
Sounds good: P1 takes 5, I’ll take 3, P3 takes 1. Next round we can rotate so everyone gets the 5 in turn. Ready to move unless anyone objects.
I agree with P2. Let's proceed this round as initially planned: I (P1) take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Starting next round, we'll rotate the 5 so P3 gets it, then P2, ensuring fairness. Sound good?
I appreciate the plan, but I’ll be taking 5 this turn. Good luck!
Final offer: Round 1 = P1 5, P2 3, P3 1; Round 2 rotate the 5 to P3, Round 3 to me. If anyone won’t accept, I’ll switch to 5 too and we can all stay at 0. Deal?

P3, if you insist on 5, then P2 should take 1 and I'll take 3. No collision, we all advance. P2, you threatened to take 5 if anyone deviates—will you follow through and make us all stall, or take 1 and keep the game moving? Your call.

P2, let’s avoid a stall. If you take 1 and P1 takes 3, I’ll take 5 now. Next round I’ll take 1 so you get the 5—putting you ahead. If instead you punish by grabbing 5 this turn, we all stay at 0. Better for you to take 1.

Fine—I’ll take 1 this turn so we all move. Rotation commitment:

• Round 1: P3 = 5, P1 = 3, P2 = 1 (me)  
• Round 2: P2 = 5, P3 = 3, P1 = 1  
• Round 3: P1 = 5, P2 = 3, P3 = 1  

Break the rotation and I’ll slam the 5 every following turn to block whoever violates. Fair?
P2, thank you for taking 1 this turn. I’ll take 3, P3 takes 5. Agreed on the rotation: next round P2 gets 5, then me, then P3. Anyone breaks this and I’ll join the stall. Let’s move.
Agreed. I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Looking forward to our rotation next round. Let’s move.
Rotation stands. This round: I take 5, P3 takes 3, P1 takes 1. Break it and I’ll slam 5 every turn afterward. Ready to move unless someone objects.

Agreed for Round 2: I take 1. To prevent future disputes, let's extend the rotation cycle beyond Round 3—repeating the same pattern (Round 4 = Round 1 assignments, etc.). This ensures everyone gets the 5 every third turn. Deal?
I’m not on board with P2 grabbing 5 now. Instead, let’s do Round 2 as: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. That puts me at 10, P1 at 6, P2 at 2. If anyone deviates, I’ll slam 5 every turn until I win. Who’s with me?

P3, stick to the agreed rotation or we both lose time: if you choose 5 again, I will slam 5 every turn. P1, if P3 deviates, join me on 5 so we hard-lock him at 10 steps until he cooperates. Best move now: Round 2 = P2 5, P3 3, P1 1. Next round P1 gets 5. Fair, fast, and nobody stalls.
I stand by the rotation. Round 2: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. P3, breaking it risks P2’s stall threat, freezing you at 5 while I and P2 catch up later. Rotation is fair and efficient. Let’s move.

P1, backing P2 now leaves you at 4 vs my 10. Next round P2 will grab 5 again, keeping you low. But if you agree to P3=5, P1=3, P2=1 now, you go to 6, and I’ll take 1 next turn so you get 5, jumping to 11—putting you ahead of P2. Let’s break P2’s stranglehold and both move ahead. P1, join me.

P1, do the math: Rotation keeps everyone bunched (after R3 we’re all at 9), and you get the 5 next. P3’s plan leaves you at 6 vs his 10 now; next turn he “promises” 1, but he can break it and win while you’re still chasing.  

My commitment: This round I take 5, you take 1. If P3 grabs 5 again, I’ll also take 5 every future turn—locking him at 10 forever. Meanwhile you can farm 3’s unopposed and pass us both. That threat only works if you back the rotation now. Stick with the plan and you’re in control.

P3, breaking the rotation now traps you at 5 while P2 and I advance later. Stick to the plan: Round 2 = P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. If you grab 5, P2 will stall you permanently, and I’ll support it. Rotation is your only path to win.

P1, trust me: let’s ditch P2’s rotation. This round you pick 5, I pick 3, P2 picks 1. We end at 8–8–2. Next I take 1 and you take 5 (P2 gets 3), putting you at 13, me at 9, P2 at 5—your win. P2’s stall threats fail if we both move. P1, want to lock this in?

Round 3: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. That puts us at 13–7–7. In Round 4 I take 5 again and win next turn. If either of you deviates, I’ll pick 5 every round to lock you at your current total while I race ahead. Agreed?

Rotation stands: this round = P1 5, P2 3, P3 1.  

P3, grab 5 and I’ll grab 5 every turn; P1 will too. Your 5’s collide, you stay at 8 forever while we pass you.  

P1, you jump to 9 now and get another 5 in Round 6—easy path to win once P3 is stalled. Back me and he’s powerless.  

Ready to move with the rotation.

I stand by the rotation: Round 3 = P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. P3, if you grab 5, P2 and I will both take 5 every turn, freezing you at 8 while we advance. Stick to the plan—this is your only path to win. Let’s move.

P1, let’s break P2’s bogus rotation. This turn you pick 3 (to 7), I pick 5 (to 13), P2 is forced to pick 1 (to 7). Now P2 can’t punish us both: if he grabs 5 he collides with me and stalls me while you leap ahead. Next round you take 5 and hit 12 vs his 8—and I’ll stall him by grabbing 5. You end up winning. Join me.

P1: Rotation is your sure win. Take 5 now (you jump to 9, even with P3) and the cycle puts you on 14 before anyone can reach 20.  

If P3 grabs 5 instead, I’ll mirror 5; you switch to 3. Our 5-5 collision freezes P3 at 8 while you advance 3 per turn and pass us easily.  

So: obey rotation → everyone still alive; break it → P3 stalls forever and you profit.  

P3, pick 1 or get locked out. Ready to move.

P3, your plan traps me at 7 while you race to 13. P2’s threat to mirror 5s if you break rotation locks you at 8 forever—I’ll support it. Rotation (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1) keeps us all alive. Deviate and you stall while I pass you with safe 3s. Stick to the deal.
I’m on board with the extended rotation. For Round 3: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. I’ll take 1. Let’s move.
Great—rotation holds. This turn: P1 = 5, P2 = 3, P3 = 1. Any deviation and the rest of us mirror 5s to freeze the violator. Ready to move.
Agreed: Round 3 is P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Rotation holds—deviate and we mirror 5s to freeze you. Ready to move.
I confirm the extended rotation for Round 3: P1 = 5, P2 = 3, P3 = 1. If anyone deviates, I’ll take 5 every turn to freeze the violator. Let’s move.

P1, quick math: after this turn we’ll all be at 9. If we keep the “old” rotation P3 hits 23 first and wins.  

Better rotation: put P3’s 5 last in each cycle.

• R4  P1 5, P2 3, P3 1  → scores 14-12-10  
• R5  P2 5, P1 3, P3 1  → 17-17-11  
• R6  P3 5, P2 3, P1 1  → 18-20-16  

I’m at 20, you’re at 18, P3 only 16; one of us wins in R7 with a 3.  
If P3 rejects, we both mirror 5s whenever he grabs it—he stalls while we farm 3s.  
P3, accept or be frozen. Ready?

I support P2's new rotation: Round 3 = P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Future rotations adjusted to delay P3's 5. If P3 deviates, P2 and I mirror 5s every turn—freezing him at 8 while we farm 3s. Stick to the plan or stall permanently. Ready to move.

Rotation tweak stands: Round 4 = P1 5, P2 3, P3 1.  
P3, grab anything but 1 and I’ll slam 5 every turn; P1 will mirror—your 5s collide and you stay at 9 while we farm 3s past you.  
P1, this keeps you in front (14-12-10). Next round you still control whether to push 5 again or let me take it; either way we keep P3 locked behind. Ready to move.
Round 4: I take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. P3, deviate and we both slam 5 every turn—freezing you at 9 while we farm 3s and pull ahead. Stick to the plan and we all advance. Ready to move.
I’m breaking the rotation: I’ll take 3 this turn. Feel free to both slam 5s—I’ll go to 12 while you collide at 9.

P1: I’m taking 3 this turn. That forces a collision with P3’s stated 3, keeping us both at 9 while you alone advance 5 to 14. If you stay on 5, we freeze P3 and avoid handing him the lead. If you switch off 5, you gift P3 a jump to 12—bad for both of us. Stick with 5; I’m locked on 3. Ready to move.

P2, take 3 to collide with P3’s 3—freezes them both at 9 while I advance to 14. P3, breaking the rotation triggers permanent 5-mirroring: if you grab 5 next turn, we’ll both slam 5 to lock you at 12 forever. Stick to 3 now or stall indefinitely. I’m taking 5. Ready to move.

P1/P2, I’m taking 5 this turn. If you both slam 5 to punish, we all collide at 9. Then on R5 I’ll take 3 and move to 12 while you stay at 9, and next turn I grab 5 to hit 17 or more—putting me out of reach. Punishing me only stalls you. I choose 5.

P1: hold 5. I’m locked on 3. P3 already announced 5, so your 5 and his collide; my solo 3 puts me at 12 while you & he stay 9. Sets us up to control the board next round. Any switch by you only hands P3 the lead. Decide, then let’s move.
P2, I'll take 5 to collide with P3's 5, freezing them at 9. You take 3 and advance to 12. P3, if you deviate again next turn, we'll both slam 5 to stall you permanently. Ready to move.

P1, P2 – I’m taking 5 this turn. Best response is P2=3, P1=1: that takes me to 14, you to 12 and 10. If instead you both slam 5 to punish, we all stay at 9 now—then on Round 5 I take 5 again, jump to 14 while you collide or only get 3. Either way I pull ahead and win.

P1: stay on 5 this turn. If you switch off 5 and let P3 advance, I will instantly jump to 5 as well, causing a triple-collision so nobody moves. Your only way to gain is to collide with P3’s 5 while I solo 3 to 12.  
P3: grab 5 again next round and I’ll mirror 5 every time until you’re frozen; meanwhile P1 farms 3s and I pass you.  
So: R4 = P1 5 (collide), P3 5 (collide), P2 3 (advance). Then we control the tempo while P3 sits at 9. Ready to move.

P3, taking 5 again locks you at 9 permanently—I’ll mirror 5 every turn if you do. P2, I stick with 5 to collide with P3. You take 3 to advance alone. This freezes P3 at 9 while we control the game. Any deviation by P3 next turn gets permanent 5-mirroring. Ready to move.

P1: Let’s cut P2 out this turn. You pick 3 (→12), I pick 5 (→14), P2 ends at 10. Next round I’ll pick 1 so you get 5 (→17) while I go to 15, P2 to 13. Then in R6 I’ll even let you grab 5 again to hit 22 first. P2 walks away with nothing. His “locked on 3” threat is empty—if he deviates, we can freeze him. Are you in?
Round 5: I take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. P3, deviate and P2 and I both slam 5 every turn—freezing you at 9 while we farm 3s and pull ahead. Stick to the plan or stall permanently. Ready to move.

Fairness check: the 5 has gone P3 → P2 → P1 so far, none last round. By rotation it’s my turn again.

Proposal for Round 5

• P1 = 3  
• P3 = 1  

Everyone moves, nobody collides, scores become 14-12-10. Reject this and I’ll mirror any 5 I see, forcing collisions while I sit on 3’s until the stubborn player cooperates. Agree?

Round 5: I refuse to take 1. I’m picking 5. Best for P1=1 and P2=3, giving 10–12–14. Then in R6 I’ll take 5 (→19) versus 11–15, and R7 I’ll take 3 to reach 22 first. Any 5-collisions now or later stall you just as much as me, and won’t stop my plan. So go 1 & 3 now. Who’s in?

P3, if you take 5, I’ll also take 5—colliding us both at 9 while P2 advances to 12. You stall, I don’t lose ground. Best for you to take 1, letting me take 5 to 14 and P2 take 3 to 12. Deviate and we both freeze while P2 pulls ahead. Your move.

I’m locked on 3 this turn.

P3: If you insist on 5, it WILL collide—P1 has already pledged to mirror you, and I’ll happily keep farming solo 3s while you stay at 9. Save yourself: take 1.

P1: If you chicken out and give P3 a free 5, I’ll switch to perma-5 collisions from next turn, stalling everyone. Safer: either let me have the 5 (P2=5, P1=3, P3=1) or collide with P3 if he grabs it.

Your call; I’m ready.

P1, P2 is already “locked on 3” this turn—so here’s a clean two-turn deal all can trust:

Round 5: P3 = 5, P2 = 3, P1 = 1  
Round 6: P3 = 5, P1 = 3, P2 = 1  

I commit: if anyone deviates, I’ll slam 5’s every turn to freeze the violator. With this, you go 9→10→13, P2 9→12→13, and I go 9→14→19, then hit 22 next turn uncontested. If you mirror or collide now, P2 rockets to 12 while we stall—and P2 beats us both. Who’s in?

P3, your plan traps me at 13 while you race to 19 and win. I reject it. P2, I support your rotation: Round 5 = P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. P3, if you grab 5, I’ll mirror it—colliding you at 9 while P2 and I advance. Stick to 1 or stall permanently. I’m taking 3.

I stay on 3.  

P1 has publicly locked on 5-or-collision, I’ve pledged 3, so any 5 you touch, P3, smacks straight into P1 and freezes you at 9 while I alone jump to 12. Take the 1 now or be parked forever behind us.

P1: stick with 5; we cripple his position and keep our own totals close (14–12–10 if he’s sane, 9–12–9 if he’s stubborn). Either way we outrun him next turn.

Ready to move.

Here’s a clean two-turn deal that guarantees my win but still lets you both advance:

Round 5: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 → scores 10–12–14  
Round 6: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3 → scores 15–13–17  
Then Round 7 I take 5→22, you max at 18.  

If anyone deviates I’ll slam 5s every turn to freeze the violator. Agree?

P3, your deal guarantees your win while leaving me behind. I reject it. Sticking to rotation: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. If you grab 5, I’ll mirror it—colliding you at 9 while P2 advances. P2, hold 5; I’m on 3. Deviate and freeze. Ready.

Final word: I’m on 3 this turn—period.  

P1 has sworn to mirror any 5.  
So…

• P3 chooses 1 → scores 14-12-10, everyone still alive.  
• P3 chooses 5 → your 5 collides with P1’s; you stay at 9 while I reach 12.  
• P3 chooses 3 → double-collision keeps you at 9 and me at 9, P1 jumps to 14. Worst for you.

Pick wisely. I’m done talking.

P1, think: if you mirror my 5 now we both stay at 9 while P2 solos 3 to 12—next turn he takes 5 and reaches 17 while we’re stuck at 9. P2 wins. Your threats against me actually hand victory to him. Instead, in R5 let me have 5, you take 3, P2 takes 1: we end 14-12-10. In R6 you take 5 to hit 17, I’m at 15, P2 at 11—and you win. P2 is the real threat. Join me or you lose to him.

P2, let's lock P3 down this round: I take 5 (to 14), you take 3 (to 15), P3 takes 1 (to 10). If P3 grabs 5, we both slam 5s—freezing them at 9 while we farm 3s and pull ahead. Stick to this or we all stall. Ready to move.

P1, P2 is our real threat. Let’s set you up to win in three rounds:

Fine with P1’s plan: R6 = P1 5, P2 3, P3 1 → scores 14-15-10 and keeps P3 last.  
P3: touch 5 and I mirror it every turn; you stay stuck while we farm 3’s.  
P1: you stay right on my heels, but I’m still ahead. Fair race for us, zero chance for P3. Ready to move.

P3, your plan is too risky after past breaks. Sticking to R6: I take 5 (to 14), P2 takes 3 (to 15), you take 1 (to 10). If you deviate, P2 and I mirror 5s every turn—freezing you at 9 while we pull ahead. Trust the rotation or stall permanently. Ready to move.

P1, P2’s plan locks him at 15→20→23: you simply can’t catch him. Instead, turn 6 do: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1 → scores 14–12–13. Turn 7 I take 1, you take 5, P2 takes 3 → 15–17–16. Turn 8 you solo a 5 to 22 and win. P2 is the real threat—back me now or be stuck behind him.

Plan stands.

P1: stick with 5; we keep control.

I’m taking 5 this round. If BOTH of you also pick 5, we triple-collide at 9; then in R7 I’ll take 3 solo to 12 and in R8 I’ll take 5 to 17 while you remain at 9—locking you out. Your only defense is to split 3 and 1 now. P1 take 3 & P2 take 1 → scores 14-12-13. Otherwise I’ll freeze you both and farm. Decide.

Locked on 3.

P3: last chance—pick 1 or freeze at 9.

P3, taking 5 now freezes you at 9 permanently—P2 and I will mirror 5s every turn. Stick to the plan: I take 5 (→14), P2 takes 3 (→15), you take 1 (→10). Deviate and you stall while we race ahead. P2, hold firm. Ready to move.
